content.description: This is a great lead for the aspiring 5.9 leader - low angle slab requiring good footwork - smearing and thin edging. It is well-protected with the crux around the 4th bolt.
content.protection: Eight well-spaced bolts, this is easily approached for toproping off of the anchors.

content.description: This is not climbed often. Follow the bolt line on the right side of Water Slabs. Follow the left edge, then turn right up a thin face (lichen abounds just to the left - hug the right side) before hopping onto a third face moving up and left.
content.protection: 10 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. Rossiter incorrectly labels it as 9 bolts.

content.description:
The thin slab moves are the crux. The roof above can be pulled at about 5.8 on clean rock.

If anyone knows the FA or route name, I'll add it to this posting.
content.protection: 6-8 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the fourth bolted route from the left on the Water Slabs.

content.description:
The crux is down low on the face. There is a rusty old ring pin you can clip in the middle of the face which could be backed up with gear, but the climbing is easy at this point. The upper roof move is about 5.7.

If anyone knows the FA or name, let me know, and I'll edit this listing.
content.protection: 6-8 modern bolts plus an old pin to a two-bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is the third bolted route from the left on the Water Slabs, about 100 feet right of

Mary Lynn's Slab

.

content.description: This is the furthest right route on the Water Slabs. The route starts up a grassy ramp about 50 feet right of bolted route #6. There is an old ring piton at start of route. Follow bolts up the slab to an anchor. The last 20 feet or so are runout on easy terrain, but there are plenty of spots/cracks to put some small to medium pro in.
content.protection: Bolts and pro at the top if needed.
content.location: It is the furthest right route on the Water Slabs. The route starts up a grassy ramp about 50 feet right of bolted route #6.

content.description:
This is a bolted route about 50 feet right of

Bolted Route #5

. Follow bolts up a slab to overlaps and roof to an anchor on the lip of a roof. We were rained off before we could climb it and do not have a rating (it looks like roofs would be in the 5.9-5.10 range). This was added here for info and direction.
content.location:
It is the bolted route about 50 feet right of

Bolted Route #5

.

content.description:
This route starts in a right-facing dihedral about 10-20 feet right of

Bolted Route Number 4

. Go up easier climbing in a crack (which takes pro) up to overlaps with bolts, follow bolts up through roof into the upper dihedral then to anchors for

Bolted Route Number 4

. When exiting upper dihedral, a climber can either put pro in crack or possibly reach over left and clip upper two bolts of

bolted route #4

.

This climb can be toproped from the anchors of

Bolted Route Number 4

. You can climb either

Bolted Route Number 3

or

#4

to reach the anchors.
content.protection: Small to medium pro down low and 5-6 bolts on the upper part of the climb.
content.location:
The route starts in a right-facing dihedral about 10-20 feet right of

Bolted Route Number 4

.

content.description:
This is the bolted face above bolted routes

#3

,

#4

, and

#5

. From anchors on

#3

or

#4

, traverse right a couple of feet, grab the horn on the arete, and pull up onto the face. Continue with dirty slab climbing to anchors at the top.
content.location:
This is a 2nd pitch or bolted face above Bolted Routes

#3

and

#4

.
